headline.main: Taliban Holdouts, Europe's Reservations and Anthrax Frustrations
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED -- AN OVERVIEW: NOV. 23, 2001

lead_paragraph: Down but not out. That seemed the simplest way to describe the Taliban in the complex arrangements under way to get their forces to surrender in Kunduz, the last northern city in Afghanistan that they hold. In fact, there were signs of new Taliban determination to carry on the struggle. DIGGING IN -- If Pakistani intelligence officials are right, non-Afghan fighters for the Taliban were digging in near Kabul, the Afghan capital, and also at two locations outside Jalalabad, in the country's northeast. Rumors spread that Osama bin Laden was with them -- not near Kandahar in the south, as generally assumed, but in an area of jagged ridges called Tora Bora. It was hard to tell what to believe. But about 800 American Special Operations forces were said to be massed in Pakistan, ready to enter Afghanistan to find Mr. bin Laden and kill him.
abstract: Overview of day's events in war on terrorism, fighting in Afghanistan and anthrax attacks
